ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned in such great depth about new ways to not only watch movies but appreciate them, critique them and identify challenges and flaws directors, actors and writers were forced to face throughout production.
I learned about movies and their roots in real life.
I watched a lot of cool movies I never would have seen otherwise.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was a very low-key course, and I like the format of watching a movie each week and then discussing it in class. However, there wasn't really a clear trajectory, and it felt like we were just watching films without there being any connection to a broader theme, movement, or history.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Class with Professor Roemer was my favorite part of the week. I looked forward to attending every Monday. My eyes were opened to classic movies that I know I wouldn't have watched on my own but am forever grateful I was exposed to through this class. Professor Roemer is a delight, he's insightful, funny and genuine. This is one of my favorite classes and I would recommend it to another student - american studies major or not.
I would recommend this course to any student who wants to spend a lot of time thinking through life's caveats through film
If you are interested in film and need a fifth class, I would recommend Fact in Fiction. Professor Roemer is really cool.
